It's easy to glorify God when you're safe, warm, well-fed, healthy, rich, beautiful, etc. To do so when you're Job and covered with sores and have lost your home and family is supposed to testify to God's ultimate goodness.  Those who say they prayed away the cancer are mistaken. Essentially they are saying that they control God. They are so freaked out about uncertainty, which is all that life really is, that they prefer religion to be like magic. That way, nothing needs to be logical or scientific. If you believe in magic for your religion, then you just need to say the right words and act certain ways and have certain attitudes and believe strongly enough, and, voila, you're going to get in the right school or get the job or be cured. If the cure doesn't happen, then you can blame a lack of  focus, a negative attitude, too much gin 20 years ago, or whatever keeps the magic real. Although I have my doubts about God quite a bit (I mostly ignore God they way my cat would ignore me when I'd return home after a long weekend away), when I am in a believing state I don't believe God causes suffering, I believe God allows suffering. It's part of the rules of the game of free will. I don't believe the cancer miracles that we hear about on the boards or in the news. It's ridiculous and reckless to claim people are miraculously cured, imo, when scientists do not understand enough about the disease and why it behaves inconsistently. None of the stories about being cured qualify as miracles. If a cancer patient died and was dead for a few days and then got up and started tap dancing again, that would be a miracle. Everything less is just a lucky event and a head scratcher--and should give scientists reason to look more closely at that patient to see how he or she differed from other patients. I don't think God intervenes--or not the way we think. I've heard some pretty astounding supernatural stories from reliable sources and family members. But nothing is provable. It's why we use the words "faith" and "belief."  I think it was C.S. Lewis who said something like, "Prayer doesn't change God, prayer changes me." That to me makes sense and makes prayer very worthwhile, even for a skeptic. I also believe this: "Pain is inevitable; suffering is optional." But that's for another thread. Back to the OP, I don't believe most of those "miraculous" cure stories. I do know that it's possible to be NED for 10 or 20 years--or maybe longer. What I don't know is how to believe that that could happen for me--and relax with that image of making future plans with the expectation that I'll be around to do them--while at the same time I focus daily on meds, infusions, scans, progression, and narrowing options. Is it possible to live both ways simultaneously--with unhindered optimism and gritty realism? If others know how, please share how you perform these mental gymnastics.

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2012 09:08AM - edited Sep 8, 2012 09:11AM by Surly Spamgril, thanks for putting those thoughts into words. I have looked at this issue from many angles over the past 2 1/2 years, and there is just no good answer or outcome. When first diagnosed my goal was to live long enough to get affairs in order, debt paid off, etc., so that my husband wouldn't be left in a precarious situation and so our house wouldn't be at risk. He owns his own business, which has never recovered since the economic downturn of 2008. And it had only half recovered from the post 9/11 economic slump. I say I'm not afraid of dying, and I don't think I am, but I don't know how we can truly know that until it is perhaps immiment. And while I don't want to imagine the grief my mother and siblings and other relatives will experience if I die soon, the hardest thing for me is imagining what is in store for my husband. He's more of a survivor than me; he wouldn't become a recluse like I would if he died on me. But we're a team. I ache thinking about his loneliness and him having to be reliant only on himself (we don't have children). He will probably be entering his retirement years alone (I'm 47; he's 57), and that is the time that we had imagined we would spend more time together enjoying life and travels and everything. One part of me wants to die sooner so that he has more time to find someone new. I would be so happy to know that he had found love and companionship again. Another part of me wants research to stay two steps ahead of my disease so that I always can glide into the next best treatment and function just fine. But, meantime, how do I chase away that dark cloud that is always hanging over us so we could imagine 10 or 20 good years together. We don't even realize how polluted that cloud is until the tension builds over something and we have a meltdown over money or pity or housekeeping. I will say that this disease has made us closer and our relationship deeper than it would have been otherwise. I am grateful for that. But there is still the sad reality of our lives and this disease. Other days I imagine I would feel better if my husband unexpectedly died first. It feels fair that he should die and be at peace and that I, whom I blame for the misery caused by my disease, should have to grieve his loss alone until the cancer gets me. This is just foolish imaginings, of course. I don't wish for it and know better than to try to will an outcome. I rarely pray. And when I pray I rarely ask for what I want. I simply ask that I be able to handle with grace whatever comes. A final thought about the word "fight." I know that people take issue with words like "fight" and "battle" when it comes to dealing with cancer. I don't feel strongly about those terms. But I must say that I really don't feel like I'm fighting cancer. I'm not a competitive person. I played sports for fun, not to win. If a friend and I both had our eye on the same guy, I would always back down. I think I have always hated the resistance and tension of any kind of fight. Instead, I think I deal with cancer by rolling with it. If I envision my life with cancer as a rapid stream, to fight it would be like clinging to a big boulder in the stream, with water smacking against it and me relentlessly. Instead, I feel like I'm on a log and am navigating my way through the rapids, not wasting my energy where I shouldn't but steering around the trouble spots and finding little coves to rest. When people say I'm a fighter because I get up and go to work every day even though I look wiped out, it just doesn't ring true. I go to work because it's better and easier than the alternative right now. It might not be next week. In some ways, I think I am managing this disease by not fighting it. I must say, however, that the emotional/psychological damage of this disease is far more painful than any physical trauma I have experienced.  If you want an answer to your question: I do think the hardships have been worth it for now. And I do think hardships are not for nought. I believe I will know when the hardships are no longer worth it. And I hope I have the courage and capacity to make the right decision when that happens. Meantime, I hope that you find love and peace in each individual moment.
